message: I've met this guy on the street and when I followed up to check his claim to blog about a song, on a
, I found out not only does he as he said, they're really in-depth poetical reviews with a slant in style. I really like your work, my friend!
Starting with this April 1st the word "fool" became something of a red groove, make sure to also look at Mr. salwarpe's other spleens!﻿
play.google.com - Real Euro Train Simulator - Best 3D Driving Game - Android Apps on Google Play
...will I dream? What do you mean?
– It is a quote from the film adaptation of
, as spoken by an AI. It's the successor of Kubrick's awesome 1969 adaptation
. In fact, Clarke has written two more sequels called
that didn't make it onto film, yet!
, and one can clearly hear the long subpolar nights (or days), and the interplay of water, light and darkness.

The fate of this band was pointing towards ice cold grey hat hacker motives from the beginning, which is sort of hard to believe if you listen to their early albums, in particular perhaps this piece that clearly shows influence from the 80'ies:
The next song on that very same album, however, features jazz poetry and compoosition style...

But with time they took up electronic instrumentation, mostly by then long out of fashion late 80's electronic sounds, approaching a clear EBM style. Here's an example with a fascinating rhythm and a nice title that I find very charming:
clock DVA - man amplified - 03 axiomatic and heuristic

And in the end we get a high ratio of incorporated text samples from news shows and maybe related movies - I don't know where from. Here's an example with a driving beat from this extraordinary album with long explanations in the booklet:
clock DVA - buried dreams - 03 sound mirror
this? I just love all of Aphex Twin's compositions. A friend told me he heard someone say that Aphex Twin did quite some of his work while dreaming, as in: while asleep.
When this video came out I only had access to a version without the long 3 minute intro, in which we find ourselves following two grossly horny guys cursing their way to the next hooker.

But when the music arrives with a seemingly tailless limo, all the girl's faces turn into Aphex', with an extra eerie grin on them. All the people (except those guys) turn out to be the very same lad who's playing the music...
Is it a metaphor? Some kind of cultural criticism? We're still human, aren't we?﻿

link.title: Aphex Twin - Window Licker
link.description: The work of Chris Cunningham & Richard D. James (Aphex Twin)

message: This is one of the pieces you'll tend to crank up further and ever louder. Notwithstanding it's mostly noise anyways. There's a lack of bass, making it a bright and clear type of row.
Jump. You want some room so you can bounce around. Maybe unpack your hard >< core posing, if you have any.
There is some kind of lyrics, I suppose they're atheists - or worse. How could one conceive an exquisit carpet of bang and shred like this appealing only to the christian gods anyways.﻿
Had to fill up my friendly tune reservoir afterwards, but forgot to turn down the volume. Met the neighbours. All of them. Nice people, even if they seemed more disturbed than usual.﻿

message: Thoughts and imaginations I had while listening to
. I've never seen the movie, but it seems my ideas are way too simple to describe what is going on there.

The first piece is a carefully arranged soundwall, wide opening space with the first tunes, inconceivable to further extend, and yet it does! It is how a grand and marvelous building must feel to a newborn.

You like that, little one? Then go learn something! This is how I percieve the second piece, as if I could almost feel the grated window's arcs. Of generous school halls, made for small people, but many of them! The theme is almost simplistic, each a progression starting clean and illuminating, before incorporating a small disturbance that propagates, until we end up with an all new unharmed harmony.

First works showing talent and intention are the sign of a forming personality. A spirit that begins remembering its shape, and the form of space, dividing it in a peculiar way. It's when education ends:
This must be freedom! High feelings pervade the time after the becoming architect has soaked up all his potential. Hardship is still sports, opponents are friends, and all workers your family.

It is funny that when the mind leaps, time might appear to run backwards, large designs unfold all by themselves from conditions set at the beginning. When the method is with you, you can watch, your hands knowing what to do.

Success of the many is always a tragic. A single day in the existence of the result can never accomodate the days to come, the wonders to be seen. The opening is a fad, meaning set in stone left to itself. Their grandeur doesn't need its creators anymore.
It is the main theme seeing its best days.
And thus becomes inhabited by spirits that weren't there before!
An eternity it seems, but really only for a very long time. The grand works of the great age, too! With age comes loss and loneliness.
The last light seen by the tip of a sinking city is a day on a sinking ship. The desert is eating, the empty is coming back.
Underground earth itself grinds down to dust whatever mankind has left on its surface. Turning up, driven by formless fervency.
This deconstruction is extasy in its own right. Leaving the result in pieces, driving out any former relations.
As if a mirror version of grandness would live down below. The preecho of a first impression. The aftershadow of a last, an empty space awaiting new meaning.

It's where the cycle closes. Augustus, ever innocent, not knowing, naked. It is a frightening experience to first see space, see it divided. The sand that contains the bones of our ancestors will be made into something wonderful!

message: "This is... ah... no offense, but you are a robot, aren't you?"
at their best. They've been collaborating since 1996 on what would only later be known as
. Mixing psychedelic ambient elements with world music (and other bizarre cruft), they'll easily get you out of your armchair dancing.
Can you help this ageing rebel? ... You crazy think you're gonna change this silly world?

project started in 1990 on the premise of providing metaphorical "food for DJs". The records consisted of collections of breaks, loops and samples, that could be used for mixing, remixing and producing.

But people liked listening to them so much, they became a success. And later albums had more "example" mixes of the material provided. Back at the time, Ninja Tune was one of my favorite labels, most of their releases quickly made way directly to my heart. Here's one of my favorite from Kaleidoscope, one of those later jazzy albums:
No matter what he would try
I gotta straiten up my head
Can you help this ageing rebel
Do you really have the stuff
Bet the bread that you'll pass the buck instead
Where a crowd of cunning listens
Don't you really know the score
You crazy think your going to change this silly world
Better see your self a shrink
Cunningly the argue about our boy
Now he's running down the dark
In an alley full of suit
Panic in his brain pulls and gets away
Losses him a foot it's a dark and evil day
Grabs the trouble by its root
So you see it seems to me a gentle kind of cruelty
Ageing rebels older a little wiser maybe too
Does he look like me and you
Think how happy mom will be
Think how happy mom will be
